questions.text: Are trusted websites immune to XSS attacks?

solutions.1: Yes they are safe because the browser checks the code before executing.
solutions.2: Yes because Google has got an algorithm that blocks malicious code.
solutions.3: No because the script that is executed will break through the defense algorithm of the browser.
solutions.4: No because the browser trusts the website if it is acknowledged trusted, then the browser does not know that the script is malicious.

solutions.1: Data enters a web application through a trusted source.
solutions.2: Data enters a browser application through the website.
solutions.3: The data is included in dynamic content that is sent to a web user without being validated for malicious content.
solutions.4: The data is excluded in static content that way it is sent without being validated.

solutions.1: The script is permanently stored on the server and the victim gets the malicious script when requesting information from the server.
solutions.2: The script stores itself on the computer of the victim and executes locally the malicious code.
solutions.3: The script stores a virus on the computer of the victim. The attacker can perform various actions now.
solutions.4: The script is stored in the browser and sends information to the attacker.

solutions.1: Reflected attacks reflect malicious code from the database to the web server and then reflect it back to the user.
solutions.2: They reflect the injected script off the web server. That occurs when input sent to the web server is part of the request.
solutions.3: Reflected attacks reflect from the firewall off to the database where the user requests information from.
solutions.4: Reflected XSS is an attack where the injected script is reflected off the database and web server to the user.

questions.text: Is JavaScript the only way to perform XSS attacks?

solutions.1: Yes you can only make use of tags through JavaScript.
solutions.2: Yes otherwise you cannot steal cookies.
solutions.4: No there are many other ways. Like HTML, Flash or any other type of code that the browser executes.
